This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

FRIDAY, APRIL 12, 1907.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION
div.p: The announcement of Lord Cromer's resignation has been received everywhere with the sincerest expressions of regret, for the career of no living statesman has been so bound up with the welfare and development of a country as has that of Lord Cromer with modern Egypt. It was known that of late his health had been waning and within the last twelve months his Lordship has aged perceptibly, but there were no suspicions that matters had come to such a pass as to necessitate his immediate cessation from the cares of State. We sincerely hope that he will still have many years yet to live and will long be spared to watch the continuous progress of the country under the guidance of his successor.

It has fallen to the lot of no other man in modem times to so completely identify himself with the Government of a foreign country in the sense of "L'Etat o'est moi" as has Lord Cromer with Egypt. At no time since the deposition of Ismail Pasha had England been confronted with a more difficult situation in Egypt, or one requiring greater influence and authority to enable her to deal with it than in the two years immediately subsequent to the return of Lord Cromer to Cairo with the reputation which he had won for years previously as a financier enhanced by a three years management of the revenues of India. It was fortunate that at that crisis in our Egyptian policy we were ablo to command the services of such a great diplomatist and administrator. Of all the great reforms which in the course of the next decade were to convert Egypt from a land of fiscal oppression and judicial corruption into a country whiolp as regards government taxation and admin straiion, will bear compari­son with any other Oriental country under

European rule, Lord Cromer was the life and soul. The memory of the public in Egypt is extraordinary short-lived and we are accustomed now-a-days to consider such portents as the Nationalist Press et hog genus omnte, assigns of troublous times, but when we consider the extraordinary difficulties connected with the reform of the Government of Egypt and the revival of her prosperity in the face of native opposition, French hostility, and indifference at home, the difficulties that have now to be contended with appear utterly contemptible.

The whole of this great work of con­struction was achieved by Lord Cromer in the teeth of constantly recurring obstacles and under the shadow of continual discour­agements It. was achieved without assist­ance from any of those European Power, who should have sympathised with the work in the name of onr common civilisation, . but amid the indifference of all, and against the covert or overt opposition of some. It was wrought through unwilling native instruments, and encountered impediments of native prejudice and native interest at every stage. Whether we look at the dimensions of the task which Lord Cromer has accomplished in Egvpt or at the multitude and magnitude of the difficulties, which had to be overcome in its accomplishment, we are surely entitled to reckon Lord Cromer's work as one of the most notable exploits in the history of Europe's dealings with the East. If England, in the words of the late Mr. Traill in his life of Lord Cromer, concentrating her strength for self-defence, were forced tomorrow to retire from Egypt—even as Rome, our prototype in history, withdrew her legions from onr own shores when her enemies gathered on her frontier—the last two decades of the nineteenth and the beginning of the twentieth century would still be remembered in the Nile Valley as a period when for the first time for countless generations, law and order and security reigned under the regis of a Power which has spread these blessings over half the world when the stream of justice flowed pure from its fount, and the rich man could no more deflect its course than he could divert the waters of the Nile from the plot of the poorest cultivator; when the hand of the oppressor was stayed over the people, and the extortions of the tax-gatherer were made to cease, and the lash was wrested from the task master, and the peasant every­where ate of the fruit of his labour, no man making bim afraid. Although tha recollection of these things may pass away in Egypt itself, for there are unfortunately sigus that the l>eople are unworthy of the benefits they havo received, yet wherever'the tale of this great and beneficent work is told, the name of the English administrator who guided ita whole course from commencement to completion, whose nuconquerable patience overcame one by one all the obstacles that impeded it, whose sagacity foresaw and whose firmness averted all the dangers that threatened it, will claim a place at the head of every chapter of the noble narrative and be recalled with honour on every page.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents ; on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: The Egyptian University.
div.p: The subscriptions up to yesterday amounts to L.E. 26,046.

div.head: Manouf Wator Supply.
div.p: It is expected that the work of installing a water supply for Monouf will be complete before the end of this year.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O, Alex andria, at 3 10 p.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Alexandria Police.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has sanctioned a new police post at Rosetta Gate. A credit of L.E. 200 has been granted for this purpose

div.head: New Lighthouse
div.p: The question of constructing a new Light house on the African shore of the Gulf of Suez; 20 miles 8.W. of Newport Bock Wight, is now under consideration.

div.head: The Report In Arabic.
div.p: "Al Mokattam" has completed the translation of Lord Cromer's. Report into Arabic. This edition will consist of 6,500 copies at against 5,500 last year.

div.head: Leprosy at Cairo.
div.p: As a number of cases of leprosy have been noticed at Cairo, it is stated that the Board of Health intends formulating some regulations on the subject of the disease.

div.head: Requiem Mass.
div.p: A mass for the repose of the soul of the late Frabricius Pasha will be celebrated on Sunday next at 10 a.m. at the Greek Orthodox Church, Hamzaoui, Cairo.

div.head: The Upper Nile.
div.p: A new book on the Upper Nile has just been published. It is entitled "A Picnic Party in wildest Africa," a Sketch of a winter's Trip to some of the unknown waters of the Upper Nile. G W.L. Buipett is the author.

div.head: The Russian Affair.
div.p: An echo of the Russian affair at Alexandria is to come up before the Italian Consular Court on the 26th inst., when Judge Herzenstein will bring an action, for libel agninst various signatories to a pamphet published duriug the popular excitement.-

div.head: Assyr in the Canal.
div.p: The mutinous Turkish troops Assyr finally entered the Canal yesterday evening in quarantine, to the great joy of the troops who were cheering for a considerable time while passing Port Tewfik They all seemed quite happy among themselves.

div.head: The Eldorado
div.p: The Eldorado theatre announces its opening for tomorrow night with a variety troupe engaged from Europe. The troupe includes Noel-Desanges, duettists, Elise Puget, Reims- Romano, Italian duettists, Piar Garcia, Spanish dancer, and several others of merit.

div.head: The Tour Eiffel
div.p: Many excellent turns are to be seen at the Tour Eiffel Theatre, which is presenting a most enjoyable programme. The principal artists include Brosa, an amusing clown with performing dogs, the sisters Letine, tight-rope walkers etc., the Sporting Trio, English singers and dancers, and Stella Nella, "high-life duettistes."

div.head: Motor-Care for Egypt
div.p: A company has been registered in London under the title of the "Argyll Motors (Continental), Limited," which has for its purpose the exploitation of the well-known Argyll on the Continent, but the operations of the new company will not be confined to Europe alone. Branch establishments will be opened in Algiers, Malta, Alexandria, Cairo, and other important centres in the North of Africa.

div.head: Port Sudan
div.p: During the past year the population of port Sudan has increased from 1,926 to 4,289. There has been a considerable influx of Europeans principally Greeks and Italians. Wages are rising there and sooneer or later the labour question will probably cause difficulties. We are glad to hear that a good many labourors are coming over from the eastern coast of the Red Pea to work at Port Sudan.

div.head: Helouan Observatory
div.p: A set of magnetographs has been placed in the Magnet house and the necessary verifications and adjustments are almost complete. As soon as these instruments are in order it will be possible to take in hand a more thorough magnetic study of this part of Africa than has been practicable up to the present time. The instrumental equipment of the observatory has beep increased by an electograph for re­cording the variations of atmospheric electricity and by a normal barometer.

div.head: An Anglo-Egyptian Invention
div.p: An automatic railway-wagon coupling, the invention of Mr. George Bain, the carriage and works manager of the Egyptian State Rail ways, is the subject of an article in "African Engineer-i ing." This coupling, in its present form, may be described as representing the latest modified design of one which has been in use in Egypt for some time. The Bain coupling possesses the advantage that it can be fitted. So existing rolling stock. All that it is necessary to do is to move the ordinary draw-hook, put the coupling bar in its place, and fit up the helical springs and the disengaging gear. The hole in the headstock may need enlarging slightly, but this is not always the Case. It is said that the transformation can be made in about an hour and half. We understand that Mr. Bain is about to make arrangements for the manufacture of the coupling in England

div.head: THE RETIREMENT OF LORD CROMER-
div.p: RECEPTION OF NEWS IN CAIRO.
HIS FAILING HEALTH.
(By Telephone).
Cairo, 1 p.m.

The feeling expressed in Cairo at Lord Cromer's retirement may be expressed in two words—"regret" and "consternation." Lord Cromer's health was known to have given some anxiety during the last two months, but, outside a very small circle, no one realised how serious was his condition.

We understand that Lord Cromer has been suffering from an utter nervous breakdown of the alimentary system, and that a complete rest and change of climate were considered absolutely necessary to ensure his recovery. We are glad to be able to state that there are no symptoms of any organic disease and we hope that Lord Cromer's retirement, however sad an event to Egypt, will have the desired results and restore to health the greatest of living Englishmen and a statesman to whom the New Egypt owes its being.
SIR ELDON GORST'S ARRIVAL.

Sir Eldon Gorst is expected to arrive on tho 21st inst and in the meantime we may advise our renders to receive with the ut- ' most scepticism nil reports relative to changes in the Ministries or among the Advisers.
BOURSE CLOSES BADLY.
The closing prices to-day at the Cairo and Alexandria Bourses show a generally down­ward tendency and buyers wene completions by their absence.

div.head: CHURCH OF SCOTLAND.
div.p: The Rev. Hugh P. Reid. Minister of Saint Andrew's, Church, Alexandria, is shortly going to Scotland on leave, and his pulpit will be occupied by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Nicol, D D., Professor of Divinity and Biblical Criticism in the University of Aberdeen. This distinguishes Scotch ecclesiastic is residing here temporarily and will take the oversight of the Mission during his stay, and to consider how the work of the Mission Schools in the city can be further developed, prior to making a tour of inspection in the Levant of the Church's Mission stations. He was born in October 1846 and married a daughter of the late Rev. John Underwood in 1878. His degrees include M. A- of Aberdeen 1868, with first class honours in classics and mental Philoso phy, Simpson Greek Prize, Hutton Prize, and Fullerton Scholarship B.D. of Ediuburgh 1871. 1).D of Edinburgh 1893 Ordained minister of Kells. Kirkcudbrightshire, 1873, he trans-erred to Tolbooth Parish, Edinburgh 1879. Duriug 1897 and 1898 he was Cr-all Lecturer, and has been convener of the Church of Scotland Jewish Mission Committee since 1896. Editor of the Mission Record of this Church 1886 to 1900 and Baird Lecturer 1906-7, his publications include, "Recent Exploration in Bible Lands," the translation jointly with Rev. Dr J.A. M'Clymont of Becks Pastroallehren des Neuen Testaments, Recent Arcaeolog and the Bible (Croall Lectures 1897-98 The Present Position and Prospects of Biblical Science (Introductory Lecture) etc.

div.head: HOME PRESS ON LORD CRQMER.
div.p: GENERAL PROFOUND REGRET.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
- - London, Friday.

Tho announcement of Lord Cromer's resignation has been received with profound regret on all hands. Both the Liberal and Conservative Press join in extolling his magnificent, work in Egypt, and lament the fact that ill-health compels him to relinquish it, this being universally accepted as the reason for his resignation.

div.head: COLLIER'S STRIKE ENDED.
div.p: This morning noon after 8 a.m. the bulk of the discharging and bunkering Arabs returned to work, and the strike, which started on March 29 may now be considered to have ended. The men have returned to work on the old rate as fur as the merchants are concerned

An agreement has, I think, been entered into by the masters and sheikhs, by which the labourers will gain a little. It is certain, however, that as far as the masters are concern­ed they will pay, the same rate for discharg­ing viz F.l 00 p8r ton as before the strike.

div.head: GREECE AND ITALY.
div.p: Yesterday there was a larg and fashionable gathering- of Greeks and Italians at the "Eldorado." Speeches were made by M. Goorgo Sarros, Greek Consul, Count Mancinclli Scotti, Italian Consul, Prof. Doni Director of the Italian School, and Messrs. Esponotos, Dimi- triadcs, L. Jurat and Dr. Jirolia. Dr. Jirolia was very enthusiastic, and his speech was frequently interrupted by cheers.
The Band of Margherita was in attendance at the ball from 3 p.m

After the meeting the two Consuls, with a crowd of fellow countrymen went to the Eastern Exchange for refreshments.When passing the Continental Hotel the procession stopped while the International Baud played the Anthems. On arriving at the Eastern Exchange another stop was made whilst the Lyre band followed suit. The International played outside the Continental, and the Lyre outside the Eastern, from 6.30 p.m. and the Margherita outside Hotel de la Poste from 9.30 till 10.30 p.m.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

The annual general meeting of the share- holders of the National Bank of Egypt was held yesterday afternoon at Cairo. The Balance sheet and profit and loss account for the year ending the 31st December last were submitted to the shareholders and approved, The Governor of the Bank, Mr. Rowlate, made the following speech : — Gentlemen,

Again this year I have the sad duty of alluding to the death of one of the most distinguished members of the Board. In the person of M. Felix Suares the Bank has lost one of its most capable and careful pilots. Not only the Bank but I may say all the community here have lost in him a sincere friend and sound adviser. Your board have elected in his place his son, M. Leon Suarfis whose - nomination we ask you to confirm.

Turning to the balance-sheet you have in your hands we propose to pay a dividend of 9% as against 8% last year which we trust you will consider satisfactory- The high rates of interests that have been the feature of the money markets during the last several months have largely accounted for this increase.

The banknotes circulation has continued to increase most satisfactorily. On the 31st December, 1906, the circulation was L.R 2 171.226, as against LE. 1 389 000 on 30th December 1905. At the present moment the circulation is L.E. 2.672.000. In this connection the more the public makes use of our notes, the less will be the temporary inconvenience, owing to the time required for the importation of gold.
Owing to the general prosperity of the country and the continuous development of our siness we shall be asking you this year to increase our nominal capital again by LStg. 5000,000.

Our relations with the Egyptian Government during the past year have continued to be most satisfactory and we hope shortly to submit for your approval an alteration in our statutes establishing us as the State Bank of tho Egyptian Government
Finally we have to thank all our staff for their capable and conscientious assistance during the last year.

div.head: EGYPTIAN YARNS
div.p: LARGE PROFITS.

The boom in the Lancashire cotton industry shows no signs of abating. In fact, the past three months has been one of the most prosper­ous periods on record. In the spinning of Egyptian counts exceptionally heavy profits have been realised. [

A number of concerns do not issue balance- sheets, but where figures are available the profit works out at about 35 per cent, per annum on the share capital. In most cases the dividend paid is at the rate of 10 per cent per addum.
On the whole, the position of spinners is well-maintained, and the margin of profit between the raw cotton and the finished yam is wide and remunerative.

div.head: SIR ELDON GORST.
div.p: LORD CROMER'S SUCCESSOR.

The appointment of Sir Eldon Gorst as the new Diplomatic Agent and Coosa' General at Cairo has two great merits, in as much as he is thoroughly acquainted with Egypt and is an extremely able man. Moreover since 1904 he has been a permanent official at the Foreign Office and has had the good fortune to have served as Assistant Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affaire under both a Conservative and Liberal Chief of the Foreign Office, so he will be able to command to the full the support of the home authorities, and his selection has the fortunate character of being in no sense a party appointment. Sir Eldon is the son of the Rt. Hon. Sir John Gorst and of the daughter of the Rev. Lorenzo Moore, of Christ Church, New Zealand. Sir Eldon was born in the Antipodes on the 25th June, 1861, when his father held the post of Civil Commissioner at Waikato. He was educated at Eton and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated as twentieth wrangler, his father having been third wrangler. On leaving the University he entered the Diplomatic Service and has held the following ranks: Attache, 1885, third Secretary, 1887, second Secretary, 1892, See rotary of Legation, 1901. He came to Egypt in 1890 and was appointed Controller of Direct Taxes and Undersecretary of State for Fin­ance in 1892. Two years later he became Ad­viser to the Ministry of the Interior and succeeded -the late. Sir Elwin Palmer as Financial Adviser in September 1898, his post, at the Interior being filled by Captain Machell. He continued to hold this post until 1904 when he joined the Foreign Office as Assistant Under-Secretary. He married Evelyn, the daughter of Mr. C. D. Rudd, of Ardhamburschan, N.B., in 1903 and has resided in London at Queen Anne's Gate.

It is worth noting as showing the unex­pectedness of Sir Eldon Gorst's appointment that on Friday last it was announced in the London Press that he would be appointed one of the three British members of the Anglo-French Commission on the subject of the New Hebrides, which is shortly to meet

div.head: THE TRIPOLI FRONTIER.
div.p: It is stated from Constantinople, that the Ottoman authorities have issued orders to Omar Ali Pasha, Mutassarif of Benghazi, Tripoli, to take the necessary measures to enforce the Awakeer Arab chiefs to settle the amount of £2,200 duo to the Shuheibar Bedouins living on the Egyptian frontier. It is also stated that the Egyptian Government will, in the near future, withdraw its troops from the frontier or station them at a distance from Benghazi.
KHEDIVlAL THEATRE.
M. DE FERAUDY.

M. de Feraudy made his first appearance last night (Wednesday) as Isidore Lechat in "Les Affaires sent les Affaires." This part he created in Paris, and he has made it his own. His thorough perception of its-full meaning, his entire grasp of every least shade of Lechat's character—the rather brutal, unscrupulous self- made millionaire, ambitious beyond bounds, as proud in his way of his great position and wealth, as were those old nobles for whom he has so supreme a contempt—his diction, gestures, expression, combine in a formidable and memorable presentment, living, sordid if you will, but impressive and terribly true. He over shadows the rest, of course, but then Mirbeau threw them into the background Mine Lechat is simply a 'bonne femme'— hardly even bourgeoise. Germaine is a hard strained creature, her ideas are hopelessly quixotic, except that she makes allowance for no one She has no sense of pity or pardon for the strong Mine Marie Fanre (who ap­peared in Mme Braude's tour as did M Gournao and M Comply) was quite good, but inclined to the superior "bourgeoise"character. Mile Van Doren was quite admirable as Germaine and used voice and expression with the fullest possible effect; she even accentuated the fact at times. The others were all suitable, and in harmony, with the play Only, M. Severin might have made more of Xavier, who should be entirely penchalant and contemptuous, without a trace of enthusiasm The play is a fine piece of work in itself, that rich man, ever a fighter, not without a certain grandeur in his force and power of rebound after every disaster, is contrasted throughout with the old regime, who live by principle. He alone is keen of sight to perceive that their fortunes, their honour, were built equally on blood oppression. They had the corvee, the high, the middle and the low justice, the droit de Seigneur, and many another fierce tort re shrouded in the dusk of their history It is Germaine who utterly fails to see this who is revolted at the credo externals, and cannot comprehend far leas admire or respect her father's real strength. His 'intendant' is a decayed noble was he not ruined through his own fault: Pherich and Gruggh are his victims, worthy scientists of ability Had not they broken Bruneau Were they not starching to break and exploit him ! One may hate Lechat but one must set against his evil aspects the strength and broad views of the man, even the detail of his evident, if rude, affection for Garraud, his natural contempt for weaklings, who are or may be what be was—and left, such might have been a knight's contempt for those less heroic fighters who failed to win their spurs- All this M. de Feraudv and Mile Van Doren revealed to us in its uncompromising reality, unforgiving and unforgiven, a fine interpretation of a fine play.

div.head: THE COMMAND IN INDIA.
div.p: KITCHENER S TERM EXTENDED
Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday. _
Lord Kitchner's term of office as Commander- in-Chief in India has been extended for a further period.
LORD CROMER'S REFORMS
REPRESENTATIVE OPINIONS. -
The "Standard" has obtained the opinions of a number of well-known Anglo-Egyptians with regard to Lord Cromer's proposals for the formation of an International Legislative Council.

Sir Edgar Vincent, who occupied the position of Financial Adviser to the Egyptian Govern­ment between the years 1883 and 1889, was seen by one of our representatives at Esher Place, Surrey, but was reluctant to speak decidedly on the matter. There is always a difficulty in criticising a country which you have not seen for 16 years," he said. Agreed, however, that Egypt was fairly stable in her history. "You may say this," he added. "There can be no question that the antiquated system of the Capitulations is altogether unsuited to the present condition of Egypt. It does little to secure the interests of Europeans, and it is often a great obstacle in the way of reforms desired by the Egyptian Government and by the Egyptian people.

"The division of the people of Egypt into two classes-foreigners, who have privileges and native born Egyptians, who have none—is undoubtedly responsible for the feeling of in­equality which has given rise to the so-called Nationalist movement. Lord Cromer's plan appears to me to meet the ease with fairness and impartiality. The foreign communities now- under consular protection, would gain rather than lose by this scheme, as they would have a more influential, voice in the direction of Government affairs than is now the case. The authority of Lord Cromer in all matters Egyptian is so great that, apart from the merits of the plan, any plan put forward under his authority (deserves the earnest support of England and the careful consideration of all the European Powers interested in Egypt. It is absurd to suppose that Lord Cromer, in putting forward his suggestion, has been influenced by any temporary display of feeling on the part of certain agitators, or by anything than his mature judgment as to what is best in the permanent interests of the country and the legitimate protection of foreign interests engaged in Egypt"

The Hon. Sydeny Peel, who has had land and intimate connection with Egypt, is a director of the National Bank of Egypt, and author of "The Binding of the Nil 'and the New Sudan," who was also seen said: "I would not presume to criticise any proposal by the Earl of Cromer : I would follow, him blindfold. I have seen enough of Egypt and the Egyptians, and I know enough of Lord Cromer to enable me to say that, without reservation Lord Cromer is not a man who makes proposals hastily and with a light heart It is hardly fair to ask me to be more specific in appreciation of the recommendations of a man the soundness of whose policy I pro­foundly trust, as I have not yet had an oppor­tunity of mastering the text of his report You say it is believed in some quarters that his hand has been forced by the Nationalists in Egypt who a few weeks ago held a large meeting and clamoured for a National As­sembly. Well, I do not believe in anything of the sort. He is not the sort of man likely to be forced by agitators or flurried by alarmists.
I may venture to say that I have never known a people more absolutely, unfitted for par­liamentary institutions than the Egyptians "
"But an international council would be quite a different affair?"

"Exactly, and whatever Lord Cromer says on that point I should be inclined to accept. More than that, I should think that he had carefully thought out his proposals, and, without having gone carefully into them, I am prepared, as I have indicated, to receive them as full of ripe wisdom."

So far as it was possible to gather yesterday the Nationalist movement in Egypt is not taken with very great seriousness by authorities best versed in Egyptian affairs, nor is it considered that Lord Cromer has gone out of his war to formulate a new scheme of Government to checkmate the aspirations of the Nationalists.

Sir Benjamin Stone, M.P, who has just returned from a tour in Egypt, was interviewed at his residence, at Erdington, with reference to Lord Cromer's proposals. Sir Benjamin Stone said: "I think that Lord Cromer's proposal of a local international legislative couucil would be conducive to stability in financial matters, and to the more expeditious conduct of business than by the more tardy process of diplomacy. It is therefore to be hoped that he will be supported in this matter.

div.head: "LA HAUTE POLITIQUE."
div.p: Saleh Ben Essaid Omar el Khalida, Presi­dent of the Central Committee of the Islamic Union, who recently arrived in Egypt overland from Tripoli, after having been ex­pelled from Malta-and Morocco, has written to the Press to deny the news given recently by an Italian newspaper in Cairo to the effect that at the request of the German Minister M Klobukowski, the French Diplomatic Agent, had decided to expel him from Egypt for having written articles against German policy. He declares the news to be false in as much as he is not a French subject but a Turk and when the French expelled him from Tunisia his Ottoman Nationality was recognised by that Power.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Count Thadee de Koziebrodski gave a dinner on Wednesday night at the Khedivial Club in honour of T.R.H. Princes George and Conrad of Bavaris, who left yesterday for Naples by Naples by the S.S. Oceana.

The German Emperor has conferred the 3rd class Order of the Crown of Prussia upon Mr. Herzbruch, president of the Cairo Mixed Tribunals, and the 4th class Order of the Red Eagle upon Dr. Dinckler, chief inspector of pharmacies, and Mr. Huber, engineer.

Lord and Lady Hastings, who have been spending their honeymoon in Egypt, have left Cairo for Italy, where they will make a tour of the lakes! Lord and Lady Hastings are returning home early in May, and intend to take a house in town for the season.
Lady Blomfield will not be "at home" on Monday next.
Ismail Pasha Sirry of the Irrigation Service, has been appointed inspector General of the basin conversion works.

Lieutenant N. B. de L. Forth, the Manchester Regiment, having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, from 15th March, with the rank of Bimbashi. The officer is posted to the 9th Sudanese.

Lieutenant Beauchamp Seymour, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, from 27th March, 1907, with the rank of Bimbashi This officer is posted to the Blue Nile District.
Dr. G. Wilmore has been appointed to succeed Dr. Purdy, who has sent in his resignation.
Mr. R. G. Garrow has been appointed chief engineer of the Esneh Barrage.
Yesterday the Rev., A. H. Longley left by the French steamer for Jaffa for a fortnight's holiday in Palestine.

Mrs. Sophia Ralli, of 96, Westbourne-ter-race, Hyde Pork, W., and of Worthing, Sussex, widow of Mr. Pandia Ralli, Greek mer­chant, left estate valued at £147,975 The testatrix bequeathed a portrait of her hus­band, by Watts, and a portrait of her son Alexander, by Araiconi, and her effects at her house at Worthing to her son Alexander; and certain pictures and personal effects to her son Pandia and her daughter Julia.

div.head: THE MAHMAL'S RETURN
div.p: Suez, April 11.

The Khedivial Mail Line steamer Rahmanieh, conveying, the Mahmal, arrived at Suez at day- light this morning, when the disembarking began at the Suez docks. The procession through the principal streets of Suez started at 4 pm. and presented a very picturesque aspect. The Holy Carpet was followed by the Governor of Suez, Ibrahim Bey Halim, N. De Turns, Chief of the Police, detachments of Infantry, Artillery, Cavalry, Coast Guards, etc., and proceeded by the military band.
The Mahmal will leave Suez for Cairo this evening by a special train.

div.head: WEDDING AT PORT SAID
div.p: On Monday last at Port Said the wedding was solemnised of Mr. W. Toms ot the Eastern Telegraph Co. Suez, and Miss Olga Nonisli, daughter of the late Vice-Consul of Suez. After the usual formalities at the British Consulate, the ceremony at the English Church was conducted by Canon Strange. The bride was given away by her brother-in-law Mr. F: Marx, and Mr. J. F. Clemow acted as best man.
After a reception at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, the happy couple left by the midday train for Cairo for their honeymoon.

At a farewell dinner at the E.T.C. Staff Mess Suez on Saturday last, Mr. W. Tom was the recipient of a tea and coffee service from his colleagues, as a wedding present. After the usual loyal toasts, the President of the Mess in a few well chosen words expressed the regret felt at the loss of so good a sportsman and companion, but the inevitable darts of Cupid had conquered, and consequently he had the pleasure of presenting to Mr. Toms a token of their regard, and wished him every happiness in the new phase of life's journey on which he was so soon to embark. Mr. Toms in reply sincerely thanked the members for their kindness and hoped it would not be an occa­sion of parting for any lengthy period he hoped to meet them all in his new home very soon, and in a preternaturally solemn tone exclaimed. "Please do not come before the fifteenth", which evoked a great deal of laughter. During the evening songs were rendered by the Rev. E. H. Blyth, Messrs. Baglehole, Waterfieldm Marshall, and Kime, and the proceedings terminated in a hearty vote of thanks to the Rev. E H. Blyth for his artistic accompaniments on the piano.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Rameses arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: Her Nerves Ruined
div.p: "So unstrung were my nerves that when anyone came near me I trembled," were the words of Mrs. M. Thorne, 130, Bridge-street West, Hockley, Birmingham, when interview­ed recently. Mrs. Thorne referred to a time when, owing to the loss of one dear to her, such a disastrous change was wrought in her that her nervous system collapsed utterly Her arm became paralysed, and for months she remained helpless. Yet to-day her nerve force has been restored, and sho, is strong of limb, having found now health through the Red, Good Blood supplied by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale Poople.

"Everyone said I was dying from anxiety and grief," Mrs. Thorne stated.. "My hands trembled and shook, and I could not rest at any time. This sudden crouble produced such a mental and physical shock that from a healthy wo­man I became a trembling, shattered invalid. My eyes were dim and sunken, and I suffered from acute melancholy and insomnia My appetite not only entirely failed me, but I came to almost abhor food of any kind. I became a fearfully emaciated, and on awakening one morning I, to my great consternation, found that I had lost the use of my right arm, which quivered heavy and useless at my ride. Then the truth flatted across .me — I was

"The limb was rubbed for hours at a stretch, without effect, and for months my arm hung helpless. I grew hysterical At the least sound, while my legs were so weal that I simply drag­ged one foot after the other. -

"For over ten months I was disabled ; then my mother who, had implicit, faith in Dr William' Pink Pills for Pale People, insisted that I should try then, 'Look' she said, pointing to a cose in the (newspapers. 'A man at Wil lesdep has been cured of paralysis by Dr. Wil­liam's Pink Pills.' So a box of these pills was purchased immediately, and I began to take them regularly. After three I tones I felt bright and cheerful, and I was astounded to find that I could enjoy a little food and digest it When I had finished the fifth box my strength began to return. I took exercise without fatigue and- could sleep peacefully at night. The right arm,, however, still hung useless by my side. Con­tinuing with Dr. Williams' Pink Pill I grad, ually experienced a tingling sensation nil over me, only slight at first, but in a few days developing all the symptoms of proper circu­lation of tho blood. By degrees my arm regained power, and I know that I was on the road to recovery. Within three months after taking the first box of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills I had regained perfect health and strength and every sign of paralysis had left me ; in fact my arm ivstronger to-day than it was before my ill-

div.head: Walker & Meimarachi, Limited
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that in conformity with a Requisition by Egyptian Shareholders an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above named Company will be hold at the Company's Office, 66, London Wall, London, E.C., on Monday the 29th April 1907 at 3 p m., for the purpose of altering the Com pany's Articles of Association with a view to transferring the Directorate and the administration of the Company's affairs from London to Cairo.

Shareholders wishing to be represented at this Meeting must deposit their Shares in the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited, Cairo or Alex­andria at latest on Or before Tuesday the 16th instant, or at the Company's Office in London at latest on or before Thursday the 26th instant.
Forms of Proxy can be obtained at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd. in Cairo or Alex­andria or at the Chambers of Maltre L. Carton de Wiart, Standard Bailding, Sharia Kasr El Nil, Cairo.
By Order 61 the BoCrd O. W. Bennet Secy, for Egypt,

div.head: RESIGNATION OF LORD CROMER
div.p: After Forty-Nine Years' Service
SIR ELDON GORST APPOINTED
Sketch of Lord Cromer's Career
The news of Lord Cromer's resignation was announced in Cairo and Alexandria yesterday afternoon at 6.30 o'clock through the medium of Reuter's Agency, which published tho following announcement:—
Sir Edward Grey has this afternoon made the following announcement in the House of Commons.

Lord Cromer has under medical advice, decided that it is necessary for him to resign for reasons of health, and I think it is best that I should read to the House tho telegram received from hiui a fbw days ago.

"I have arrived at the conclusion that I must ask you to accept my resignation. I have done so after very full consideration and con-ulta- tion with my medical adviser and Sir Stephen Mackenzie, who is here I am most anxious that it should be particularly understood that the reasons which have induced me to take this step are wholly due to the state of my health, and that no political considerations of any kind whatsoever are in any way connect­ed with it. More especially I desire to say that nothing could be more effective or generous than the manner in which the present Govern­ment has supported me. It has been the greatest pleasure to me to serve under you, and it is with extreme regret that I shall break my official connection with you. After spending, however, forty-nine years in the public service, I am thoroughly worn out, and I am really unable to support any longer tho excessive strain which my work here entails. I feel also that I do not possess the health and strength which are necessary to do justice to all the very important interests involved. Both doctors are quite agreed that it is necessary that I should give up the work."

The news has caused the greatest regret to us and will do so to the House; to me per­sonally, it means more than I can express We have relied and placed our confidence in Lord Cromer, as successive British Govern­ments have done for many year-. Some further correspondence has passed in the hope that Lord Cromer's decision might not be final, but, in view of the fact that the recovery of his health (of which I am glad to think there is the prospect) depends absolutely upon his retirement, we have been obliged to accept his decision.

There will be other opportunities for dwel­ling more at length upon his work in Egypt, but I should like to say at once that it is the object of his Majesty's Government to maintain that work and to continue the policy which-bos been inspired by him, and of which the most admirable exposition is con­tained in his last Report j st presented to Parliament.

I do not underrate the difficulty of con­tinuing without him the work which has been so dependent upon him. His retirement from Egypt is the greatest personal loss which the public service of this country could suffer. In the early years of the British occupation, in view of all the difficulties in Egypt and else­where, the success achieved by him would have seemed incredible but for the fact that he accomplished it And, if in later years,, progress has been facilitated by the prestige and confidence which have attached to the occupation, it is by Lord Cromer himself that the prestige and confidence have been creat- d,

Tho King has approved of tho appoint­ment of Sir Eldon Gorst to the vacancy at Cairo, an appointment which has been made after consultation with Lord Cromer. Sir Eldon Gorst has special knowledge of Egypt; there is no one who has possessed to a greater degree Lord Cromer's confidence or has been more closely associated with him personally in his work, and I am confident that this choice is the one best calculated to maintian and continue it.

The biography of such a ruler of men will some day he a fascinating study, but it cannot be written now. The greater part of a diplomatist's work lies beneath the surface and cannot be dug up till the matter of his negotiations has become ancient history. The following details will, however, help to give our readers an, outline of his origin and career.
THE BARING FAMILY.

The family of Baring, originally of German extraction, but for now two centuries domi­ciled and naturalized citizens of England has for more than half that long period been conspicuous in the world of British commerce, finance, and politics. Its founder, John, son of Franz Baring, a Lutheran minister of Bremen, came to England in the year 1697, and established himself as a merchant and cloth manu- facturer at Larkbeer, in Devon hire. His son Francis, horn at that place in 174", was sent to London to study commerce under a leading firm of city merchants Though deaf from his youth, his indomitable energy enabled him to overcome all obstacles, and to establish his business oanthe surest foundationa He prospered exceedingly and, had risen to wealth and importance by the time he had reached middle age. Towards the end of the century, when Pitt had determined to strengthen the titled Orders with an infusion of new blood from the middle classes, Francis Baring was a personage of sufficient prominence in the com­mercial world to have become a natural object of the Minister's selection. The baronetcy he obtained was the first of a series of distinctions attained by a family which, during the last sixty years, has added no fewer than four new titles to the roll of Peers.

Alexander, second son of tho first Baronet, was created Lord Ashburton in 1835. Thomas, grandson of Sir Francis, was raised to tho Peerage in 1866 as Baron Northbrook, a dignity exchanged in 1876 for the Earldom now held by his son, the distinguished states­man who in the last-mentioned year concluded his term of office as Viceroy of India. In 1885 another of Sir Francis's grandsons, Edward Charles Baring, was created Lord Revelstoke ; and in 1892 his younger brother Evelyn com­pleted for the present the list of the family honours by his elevation to the Peerage under the title of Lord Cromer—
EARLY YEARS.

Evelyn Baring was born on February 26th, 1611, the sixth child of his father Henry Baring's second marriage. From his mother, a daughter of Vice-Admiral Windham, and a woman of high culture, moving in a brilliant literary society of which George Grote the historian and Arthur Helps were members, he himself derived that marked literary bias of which those who enjoy his intimacy are so often and in so many ways reminded. After a year or two at a preparatory school, kept by Rev. Bickmore, he was transferred to the Ordnance School at Carshalton, the well-known training seminary for the scientific branches of the army. Thence be migrated at the age of thirteen to Woolwich Academy and passed out into the Artillery in 1858 in his eighteenth year

His military career was uneventful as the two great opportunities for active service during the middle years of the last century— the Crimean War and Indian Mutiny—had route and gone. Early in the sixties he was A.D.C. to Major-General Sir Henry Knight Storks in the Ionian Islands, which were then on the eve of being handed over to the nation to whose commercial qualities tribute was paid in the speech to which reference has just been made. In 1866 Lieut Baring was Secretary to the Commission which inquired into the Jamaican rising. In 1868 he was given A captain's rank, and entered the Staff College Between 1872 and 1876, as Private Secretary to his cousin, Lord Northbrook, who succeeded Lord Mayo as Viceroy of India, Captain Baring had exceptionally favourable opportunities for the study of the problems, civil and military, which beset the Government of the great dependency The results of his military studies were embodied in a series of "Staff College Essays" and a translation of a German text-book, which attracted no little attention. In 1875 he was given his majority in "the gunners,' and in 1879, soon after the purchase of the Suez Canal shares by the British Government, he retired from the Army, and took the appoint­ment of Controller-General of the Egyptian Finance with M. de Blignieres.

The Frenchman, however, complained of the dominant influence of his colleague, and Down­ing Street, utterly oblivious of the fact that Baring was the one man to enhance British in­terests in Cairo, sent him to fill a post that was apparently more in accord with his disposition and previous training—the post of Minister of Finance of India. It was a grave mistake, and one that cast Great Britain the expenditure of ranch treasure and the loss of mamy lives. Had Baring remained in Cairo, the revolt of Arabi Pasha in 188: would probably not have taken place.

As financial member of the Council in India he left behind him at Calcutta the record of three successive budgets. In 1883 after the de­feat of Arabi, Downing Street wisely saw fit to recall Baring from India and to make him Agent and Consul General. It was thus that Cromer's real diplomatic career in Egypt began.

At this time Egypt was virtually bankrupt, its administration almost hopelessly corrupt, and its very existence threatened by the forces of fanatinlrtn. Compare this picture with that presented by Egypt and the Sudan to­day. Many men have contributed to tho change, but the motive power behind them all has been Lord Cromer.
It is unnecessary to review Lord Cromer's career in Egypt as it would involve giving an accent of the whole course of Egyptian history frura 1883 to the present day.
LORD CROMER AND GORDON.

One of the most interesting chapters of Lord Cromer's life, when it comes to Ig- written, will be that dealing with b s relation? with Gordon. It is evident that he changed his mind about the employment of Gotdon and Znbeyr and an expedition from Suskin to Berber. How far these changes were due to the vacillations of Downing Street we cannot now tell. Lord Cromer lathe last man in the world to vindicate himself at the expense of his Government, and this century will be far on its way before wo learti the whole truth. We believe that if Lord Cromer, had then possessed the commanding in­fluent which he now exerts, and had firmly pressed a vigorous policy upon Lord Granville, he would have compelled the feeblest of modem Administrations to walk in his path. But one must not forget that he was hardly settled in the saddle when the trouble began, and that his-prestige was then not to be compared with his present reputation. On the whole, we must accept the warm testimony of Sir Henry Gordon to the earnest sympathy and unflagging support accorded to his heroic brother by the English Consul-General.
PERSONAL TRAITS.

It is of interest at the present moment to reproduce the following account of his methods of procedure and personal traits contributed by an intimate friend to the late Mr. Traill's life of Lord Cromer

"The work in Egypt grew upon the English representative, but it was work under imposed conditions. The necessity of fiscal reform was admitted on all sides, but beyond this Lord Cromer was not given a perfectly free band. He was to work on the lines of Lord Dufferin's celebrated despatch, and this documents: pre scribed certain conditions which were attractive on paper but difficult to establish in practice. Lord Dufferin could not boldly place Englishmen at the head of the various departments, but leaving the native Pashas in their high offices he provided each of them with an English Under-Secretary, who was to guide and influence him in his administrative duties. Had each of these subordinates been endowed with the tact or sympathetic dexterity, as well as with the unexampled experience of Lord Dufferin himself, the result might have been successful, but when the Undersecretary was deficient in those gifts friction immediately resulted.

"However, Lord Cromor had to carry out the programme as best he could with the materials that he found provided for him. One by one he took in hand the various de­partments, and laboured to substitute ordor for chaos, honesty for corruption, and industry for inertness. The hardest task was, and is still, to develop in native officials a sense of responsibility and self-reliance. Timid and suspicious, nurtured in a hot atmosphere of gossip and intrigue, fo-id of subterranean ways and tortuous paths to promotion, the Egyptian <1 d not take kindly to the English rtgime, be cause be did not and could not believe in it He cannot understand even now that hard work, and not backstairs influence, is the pass­port to promotion ' . .

" His philosophy leads him to take kindly vio'vs of men. Ho likes to think generously of those about him, and ho often says that as ho grows older he think* better of tho rank and fils of humanity than ho did when young All those who have worked under him feel that ho trusts them, and that ho requires at their hands equal candour. He losea no oppor­tunity of praising his subordinates and. of recommending them for promotion i. but ho requires from them staunch and thorough loyalty in return. His attitude towards his men is not unliko that of Dr. Arnold, of Rugby, when ha said that ho mutt have confidence in the Sixth.'

" l«rd Cromer's resemblance to the great Headmaster is specially shown in bis rela­tion* with tho junior member* of hi* staff. Tho Agency at Cairo is an excellent diplo­matic school. The Chief treats hi* subordinates with perfect frankness, and the result is that he is served with unswerving devotion. Ho requires thoroughness and lird work. Hi* conversation—rich in quotations, historical references, and shrewd criticisms of men and thing* - is full of instruction and stimulating suggestion. Dull indeed must that Secretary bo who does not learn something from the daily talk Lord Cromor pours out over tho luncheon table. In his relations with his ' boys, ' and above all in his happy domestic life, the warmth of heart that underlies the brusquo manner is apparent. For one of the youDg men who was associated with him in the most trying time in his Egyptian career he cheri­shed, as he has himself told us, a fatherly nflection ; and those who law his sorrow at the untimely death of Gerald Portal realized that, like all the other sides of Lord Cromer's character, his aftccticns are strong. There is nothing weak or superficial in the man.

"Sir Alfred Milnor pointed out wheo sketching the difficulties of the Egyptian problem, that it required above all other things patience; and indeed without this, tact, energy, financial adroitness, and financial ability would iiave availed little. Lord Cromer knows better than most men how to wait without losing time, when it would be inopportune to push one of his chief projects, for which ho never loses a moment, bat tarns aside and put in some smaller Work Which is auxiliary to tho main object. And the name of these tasks is legion. The British Agent and Consul-General is the universal referee, and is applied to by petitioners of every nation, and in all causes ecclesiastical and civil.'

"In a single morning ho may bo requested to give his verdict on a proposed economy on the Budget, on the dismissal of a postman,-80^ plan for augmenting the Army, on a quarrel between two rival Jewish sects, on tho deporta­tion of a drunken Irishman, on a question of precedence of tho wives of two Egyptian officials, and on the boat method of preserving the remains of a Ptolemaic temple. These add a score of other matter* pass in review before 'the spectacled ejrea,' and are investigated And adjudicated on with a care and thoroughness alike untiring and inexhaustible. And daring six moftths of the year to these multifarious dutios are added social engagements—luncheon parties, dinner partios, and receptions to 'ail and sundry1 who may be furnished with letters of introduction to the Agency—noftomention interviews with journalists and members of Parliament who wish to prove the Occupation, a failure, and projectors whose nottrumt. have ofily to be tried and paid for to convert it into a triumphant success.

"All these claimants in turn receive ap-s. propristo treatment. They are not sent away with frothy assurances of support which moan nothing, enforced by emphatic shakes of tho hand which mean less. The? are not snubbed or handed over to an Undcr-Secretary; each has his claims listened tc{ and he may be sure that if Lord Cromer has promised to write a letter on the matter that letter will be written before the day closes, and in his noxt interview he will find that his proposal has been tho­roughly sifted, and subjected to a glance as penetrating as a search-light.
LITERARY TASTES.

"My sketch has shown Lord Cromer as an indefatigable worker. Ho is also an omni­vorous reader, but with a high critical standard. He likes no inferior work. This is largely owing to tho (act that he lays a sound foundation Like Coleridge, he regards tho Bible as the 'Statesman's Manual' Few divines know the Book of Job and the prophecies of Isaiah better; bat though again with Cole­ridge he would say that 'Sublimity is Hebrew by birth,' he begins every day with a page of Greek or Latin authors. Ho loves his Homer. Tho 12th Book ot the Iliad is his favourite, Cicero and Juvenal ho erjoys. His favourite study is history, and his favourite period the French Revolution. Indian questions of course interest him keenly.

"His knowledge of the English poets is remarkable Dryden's masculine verse attracts, him, but his voluminous nute-bioks contain extraots from writers of every contury. He loves a good novel and enjoys healthy stories, like those of the now romantic schools of novelists; but he never fails to express his loathing of the nauseous fiction of the day, and has been known to put ehancejfound volumes of it into the first fire he coaid find alight
"Among his favourite passages from the Latin poets may be cited the ndble ljoes of Claudian on the maternal and beneficent function of Imperial Rome :— . j
" 'H»o est ia grwnldm viotos tjuiu sols recopit Humsnumquo genuscunmuni nomine fovit Matris non d -minsi ritu, civesque crcavit Quo* domuit, neiuquo pio loaginqua rerinxit.

Hac p-tcificis d*b«rius moribu* on-nes Quod relutipstris regioaibut aliturbospes Quo I sodom mutant licet : quod o-ruere Thulem Lusus, et horrendos quondam peuotrare revenue Quod bibimus passim Khodanum potamos Oroatcm Quod ouucti gens uns sumo*.'

"Will any Egyptian pnot ever celebrate tho beneficent work of England in the nineteenth century as Claudian celebrated tho work of Rome in the filth I It seems as if we should be ton sanguine to expect such such a eulogy, thoughit would be in many respects just Atall eyenta, such a pauegyric would be incomplete without a tribute to the man who has been 'the voice of England in Egypt,' and who has directed her efforts for good with such dis­tinguished vigour, wisdom, and perseverance— Evelyn Baring, Lord Cromer."
LORD MILNER'S TESTIMONY.

Side by side with this nnofficial testimony to the great qualities of the Consul-General let us place the no less admiring estimate formed of im by one of the ablest and most distinguish­ed of the Englishmen who served under him— in fact if not in form—during the darkest end most difficult years of the British Occnpa- lion, and recorded in what has become the standard work on this remarkable chapter in onr history. Sir, Alfred Milner writes (England in Egypt, p. 437) as follows :

"In the art of government the Englishman seems to lie as handy and adaptable as he is clumsy and angular in society. There are other nations with equal and perhaps greater gifts for the creation of an ideally perfect administration, if they have a tabula rasa wherein to construct ifc But I doubt whether any of them could have made anything at all of a system so imperfect, so inoongruous, and so irritating as that which we found in Egypt, and which we have not been permitted radioally to alter. Tho logical Frenchman would have been mad­dened by its absurdities. The authoritative temper of the German would have revolted ot its restrictions. They would have insisted on governing in their own way, or they would havo despaired of governing at all It needed that incarnation -of compromise, the average Briton, to accept the system with all its faults and set to work, quietly plpdding away to do the beat he could under untoward circnm- I stances.

| "The qualities of tho race have triumphed I But onr success might have been leas com-; perhaps that success might never have attained at all had iiXTbeen for one remarkable piece of good fortune. The stars were indeed gracious when at the beginning of onr greatest troubles it occurred to the British Governtaent to entrust the conduct of its policy to the hands of Sir Evelyn Baring It would be difficult to overestimate what the work of England in Egypt owes to the sagacity, fortitude, and patience of the.British Minister. His mental and moral equipment—very re­markable in any case—was peculiarly suited to tho veiy peculiar circumstances in which ho fo'.nd himself placed. Perhaps the most striking'feature about him has been a singular combination of strength and forbearance ; and he needed both these qualities in an excep­tional degree. jOu one side of him were the English officials, zealous about their work, fretting at the obstruction which met them every time, and constantly appealing to hi ml for assistance to overcome it. On tho other side were the native authorities, new to our methods, hating to be driven, and keen to resent the appearanco of English diplo­matic pressure. The former were often induoed to grumble at him for interfering too little, the latter were no less. prone to complain of his interfering too much.

What a task was his to steer an even keel botweon meddlesomeness and inactivity I Yet how soldoih has he failed to hit the right meau. Slowly but surely he has carried all his main points. And he has carried thorn without need- sly overriding native authority or/ pushing his own personality into tho foreground. He has realized that the esseneo of onr policy is-to hel(i the Egyptians to work out as for as possible their own salvation. And net only has no realized this himself, hot he has taught others to realize it."
RECEPTION OF NEWS

As soon as the communication was publish­ed yostorday evening tho nows spread "like wildfire" throughout Cairo ami Alexandria. Tho bouraoat Alexandria, usually comparative­ly deserted at 7 p.m., presented an animated appearance^ owing to tho numerous groups of persons discussing tho uows This morning the bourso at Alexandria-opened in a somewhat undecided condition. It is, however, generally recognised by the European public that the policy of England in Egypt will not bo altered. The immediate, announce mont of Sir Eldon Gorpt's appointment has been of considerable servicedn calming any ap­prehension, na.be is so well-known in Egypt, It has already beon mooted thit an inter­national subscription should be started in Egypt to present I»rd Cromer with a testi­monial of the esteem with which his invaluable services are regarded throughout the country.
SIR STEPHEN MACKENZIE.

Sir Stephen Mackenzie, M D., F R.C.P, wham Lord Cromor cpAsulted before sending in his resignation, is one of tho best known physicians of the^present day. He graduated at the universities of Aberdeen and Berlin, and also studied at Christ's and Loudon hospitals. He wss for some time lecturer on medicine and pathology at the London Hospital Medical College, anrt he is still' consulting physician to t(ie London, Poplar and Royal London Ophthalmic hospitals. Sir Stephen Mackenzie spends every winter in Egypt, passing most of his time at Assouan.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Director General of the Census has the honour to remind the public that in accord once with the Deere of the 10th November 1906, the Census of the population will take place on the night of Monday the 29th April.

With a view to carrying out the provisions of the above Decret, a preliminary Census is being taken bv means of Enumerators, who are authorised to ask the questions indicated in the Ministerial Arrlty of the 9th December 1906, and to take down the replies given to those questions./
This preliminary enumeration will he check ed and brought up to da'e during the night of the 29th April, as aforesaid.
The public is requested to be good enough to assist the enumerators in their duties bo that the Census may be carried out with the greatest possible accuracy. 300I2-8M

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT
div.p: Tenders will be received at the Office of the Financial Secretary to the Sudan Go­vernment, War Office, Cairo, up to 12 noon, on the 10th day of April, 1907 for the sopply of: —50,000(fiftythousand) Maria Theresa dollars, to be delivered at Suakin.
Persons wishing to tender for this idjsdioa tion can consnlt the specification at the above Office any day from 9 am. to 1 p.m. except Fridays and general holidays.

div.p: NOTICE

The Municipality of Alexandria will proceed on June the 11th. next to appoint assistant engineers to the following positions.

One temporary chief assistant and four temporary assistant engineers with exporionceof sewerage on-a large scale : preference will bo givon to candidates who have bad experience of Sen-Outfall works and pumping, and who havo a recognized Civil Engineering diploma.
